reference.title: DITA 1.3 proposed feature 13116
reference.shortdesc: Proposal to add the <cite> element to the content of title, xref, and other title-like elements.

section.title: Date and version information
section.p:
Include the following information:
Revised draft with expanded scope completed on 2/5/2013.
First draft of proposal completed on 121312.
Initial proposal approved on 090412.

section.title: Use cases
section.p: DITA users want to be able to add <cite> to <shortdesc> so that they can add a text reference to the topic short description. In Chinese and other Asian and Arabic source languages, there is no italic, which might be used to indicate a citation. When the authors use the <phrase> element for the citation, the translator must to add <i> to the translation because <phrase> is used for information that citations in many DITA topics. Organizations prefer to avoid asking the translators to add an element to the translation. In many translation workbench systems, translators are unable to change an element. Using <cite> is the best solution for both Chinese and English.

In addition, there are cases where a title may need to mention the title of a work, e.g., in a course on The Old Man and the Sea, you want something like:<learningContent id="old-man-and-sea-01"> <title>Understanding <cite>The Old Man and the Sea</cite></title> ... </learningContent>
When a title has <cite>, it follows that cross references to that title would need to allow <cite> in order to mirror the content of the title of the referenced topic or map.

section.title: Proposed solution
section.p: Add the <cite> element to the basic-phrase-no-xref content model group, allowing it to occur in <title>, <shortdesc>, <dthd>, <ddhd>, <glossterm>, <xref>, <cite>, <fragref>, <mainbooktitle>, <booktitlealt>, <booklibrary>.

An alternative would be to allow <cite> only within the title.cnt content model group, which would limit it to <title>, <shortdesc>, <dthd>, <ddhd>, <glossterm>. But in that case, cross references to titles that contained <cite> would not, themselves, be able to contain <cite>. Thus it seems to make more sense to use the more inclusive solution.

ul.li: This addition will benefit authors who require a citation to a referenced text and want to include that information in the title, short descriptions, and similar title-like contexts.

This addition will benefit authors in languages that do not use <i> as a formatting standard for citations but require that an italic font be used for citations in languages to which that styling applies.
Providing a semantic construct for this information will improve consistency across topics no unavailable because of the restrictions imposed on inline elements in <title> and <shortdesc>.

section.title: Technical requirements
section.p:
Provide a detailed description of how the solution will work. Be sure to include the following details:
DTD and Schema modifications
Topic or map specialization None
Domain None
Element Modify the definition of the definition of the basic.phrase.noxref content model group to include <cite>.
For DTDs:<!ENTITY % basic.ph.noxref "%boolean; | %cite; %keyword; | %ph; | %q; | %term; | %tm; | %state; " >
For XSDs: <xs:group name="basic.ph.noxref"> <xs:choice> <xs:group ref="ph"/> <xs:group ref="term"/> <xs:group ref="q"/> <xs:group ref="state"/> <xs:group ref="boolean"/> <xs:group ref="keyword"/> <xs:group ref="tm"/> <xs:group ref="cite"/> </xs:choice> </xs:group>
For RNC:basic.ph.noxref = boolean | cite | keyword | ph | q | term | tm | state
For RNG: <define name="basic.ph.noxref"> <choice> <ref name="boolean"/> <ref name="cite"/> <ref name="keyword"/> <ref name="ph"/> <ref name="q"/> <ref name="term"/> <ref name="tm"/> <ref name="state"/> </choice> </define>
Attributes None
Processing impact Processors would need to expect <cite> in title and shortdesc and similar contexts. Note, however, that because <title> allows <ph> today, processors already need to be prepared to handle pretty much any inline element in titles, so this should have no practical effect on processors.
Overall usability
This proposal would improve usability of the short description.
Pro The use of <cite> in <title>, <shortdesc>, and similar contexts will simplify authoring by providing the correct semantic element to the authors.
Con None

section.title: Costs
section.p:
The impact would be as follows
Little or no effect on existing processors.
DITA community-at-large would perceive this change as a minor improvement in convenience.

section.title: Examples
section.codeblock: <concept id="topicid"> <shortdesc>This concept refers to the work detailed in the following reference text: <cite>Chicago Manual of Style</cite>.</shortdesc> ... </concept>
<learningContent id="old-man-and-sea-01"> <title>Understanding <cite>The Old Man and the Sea</cite></title> ... </learningContent>
